statement.p: The graph below shows the fuel consumption (in miles per gallon, mpg) of a car driving at various speeds (in miles per hour, mph).
(click on image to enlarge)
(a) How much gas is used on a 400 mile trip at 80 mph?
amount of gas = gallons
(b) How much gas is saved by traveling 60 mph instead of 70 mph on a 600 mile trip?
saved gas = gallons
(c) According to this graph, what is the most fuel efficient speed to travel?
most fuel efficient speed = mph

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) At 80 mph, fuel consumption is about 24 mpg, so fuel used is 400 / 23.9188079597599 \approx 16.7 \ \mbox{gallons}.
(b) At 60 mph, fuel consumption is about 30 mpg, so fuel used on a 600 mile trip is 600 / 30 \approx 20.2 \mbox{ gallons}. At 70 mph, fuel consumption is about 27 mpg, so fuel used on this trip is 600 / 27 \approx 22.1 \mbox{ gallons}. Altogether we would then save 22.1 - 20.2 \approx 1.9 \mbox{ gallons}.
(c) The most fuel efficient speed is where mpg is a maximum, which is about 55 mph.

statement.p: Based on the graphs of f(x) and g(x) below, answer the following questions. If a question has more than one answer, fill in your answer as a list of values separated by commas. Thus for example if you think f(x) = g(x) when x = 20, when x = 25, and when x = 29, you would enter 20, 25, 29 (or any other order of these three numbers separated by commas).
(a) Find f( 5.2 ) =
(b) Fill in the blanks in each of the two points below to correctly complete the coordinates of two points on the graph of g(x).
(c) For what value(s) of x is/are f(x) = 2.9?
(d) For what value(s) of x is/are f(x) = g(x)?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) f( 5.2 ) = 2.9. The y-coordinate of the point on the graph of f(x) when x = 5.2 is y = 2.9.
(b) ( 6.1 , 4.9 ) and ( 2.2 , 2.9 ). The y-coordinate of the point on the graph of g(x) (the dashed line) when x = 6.1 is y = 4.9. Similarly, the x-coordinate of the point on the graph of g(x) (the dashed line) when y = 2.9 is x = 2.2.
(c) There are three points on the graph of f(x) which have a y-coordinate of 2.9: x = 2.2, 5.2, and 6.9.
(d) Two functions are equal when their graphs intersect. The graphs of f(x) and g(x) intersect at two points, when x = 2.2 and 6.1.

statement.p: The table below A = f(d), the amount of money A (in billions of dollars) in bills of denomination d circulating in US currency in 2005. For example according to the table values below there were $60.2 billion worth of $50 bills in circulation.
a) Find f(20) =
b) Using your answer in (a), what was the total number of $20 bills (not amount of money) in circulation in 2005?
There was a total number of billion $20 bills in circulation.

c) Are the following statements True or False?
There were more 20 dollar bills than 100 dollar bills
There were more 5 dollar bills than 20 dollar bills

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) f(20) = 110.1 because when the entry in the top row is 20 , the corresponding entry below it is 110.1.
b) The value 110.1 from part (a) indicates the total value (in billions of dollars) of $20 bills in circulation, not the number of $20 bills. The total number (in billions) of $20 bills in circulation equals the total value in circulation, f(20) = 110.1, divided by 20 (the value of each $20 bill): \frac{ 110.1 }{ 20 } = 5.505 \mbox{ billion $20 bills}.
c) Using the same logic as in (b) calculate the number of each bill in circulation by finding the total value in circulation, f(d), and dividing by the value of the bill, d. Then compare the number of each bill in circulation, \frac{ f(d) }{d} , for the given values of d in order to determine whether the statements are true or false.

statement.p: Let f(t) denote the number of people eating in a restaurant t minutes after 5 PM. Answer the following questions:
a) Which of the following statements best describes the significance of the expression f( 4 ) = 21?

li.p: There are 4 people eating at 5:21 PM
There are 21 people eating at 5:04 PM
There are 21 people eating at 9:00 PM
Every 4 minutes, 21 more people are eating
None of the above

statement.p: b) Which of the following statements best describes the significance of the expression f(a) = 20?

li.p: a minutes after 5 PM there are 20 people eating
Every 20 minutes, the number of people eating has increased by a people
At 5:20 PM there are a people eating
a hours after 5 PM there are 20 people eating
None of the above

statement.p: c) Which of the following statements best describes the significance of the expression f( 20 ) = b?

li.p: Every 20 minutes, the number of people eating has increased by b people
b minutes after 5 PM there are 20 people eating
At 5:20 PM there are b people eating
b hours after 5 PM there are 20 people eating
None of the above

statement.p: d) Which of the following statements best describes the significance of the expression n=f(t)?

li.p: Every t minutes, n more people have begun eating
n hours after 5 PM there are t people eating
n minutes after 5 PM there are t people eating
t hours after 5 PM there are n people eating
None of the above

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) The input 4 corresponds to the number of minutes past 5 PM, and the output 21 indicates the number of people who are eating in the restaurant at this time. Thus the mathematical expression f( 4 ) = 21 means there are 21 people eating at 5:04 PM.
b) The output 20 indicates the number of people who are eating in the restaurant at a particular time (in minutes after 5 PM). Thus the mathematical expression f(a) = 20 means a minutes after 5 PM there are 20 people eating.
c) The input 20 corresponds to the number of minutes past 5 PM. Thus the mathematical expression f( 20 ) = b means there are b people eating at 5:20 PM.
d) The t corresponds to the time (in number of minutes past 5 PM), and the output n indicates the number of people who are eating in the restaurant at this time. Thus the mathematical expression n = f(t) indicates there are n people eating in the restaurant t minutes past 5 PM. None of these statements explain this correctly, so the answer is None of the above.

statement.p: Chicago's average monthly rainfall, R = f(t) inches, is given as a function of the month, t, where January is t = 1, in the table below.
(a) Solve f(t) = 3.4.

The solution(s) to f(t) = 3.4 can be interpreted as saying
Chicago's average rainfall is least in the month of August.
Chicago's average rainfall in the month of August is 3.4 inches.
Chicago's average rainfall increases by 3.4 inches in the month of May.
Chicago's average rainfall is greatest in the month of May.
None of the above
(b) Solve f(t) = f(5).

The solution(s) to f(t) = f(5) can be interpreted as saying
Chicago's average rainfall is greatest in the month of May.
Chicago's average rainfall is 3.5 inches in the months of May and July.
Chicago's average rainfall is 3.5 inches in the month of May.
Chicago's average rainfall is 3.5 inches in the month of July.
None of the above

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The table shows f(8)=3.4, so t=8. Chicago's average rainfall in the month of August is 3.4 inches.
(b) First evaluate f(4)=3.5. Solving f(t)=3.5 gives t=5 or t=7. Chicago's average rainfall is 3.5 inches in May and July.

statement.p: A national park records data regarding the total fox population F over a 12 month period, where t = 0 means January 1, t = 1 means February 1, and so on. Below is the table of values they recorded:

(a) Is t a function of F?
Yes
No
(b) Let g(t) = F denote the fox population in month t. Find all solution(s) to the equation g(t) = 125. If there is more than one solution, give your answer as a comma separated list of numbers.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) No. For many of the values of F in the table, such as F = 100, there are multiple values of t for which F = 100 (namely when t=2 and t=10).
(b) When g(t) = 125 there are 125 foxes. We want to know what month there are 125 foxes. The table tells us that this occurs when t=2 and t=10 . This means the population of foxes is 125 in March and November.

statement.p: An open box is to be made from a flat piece of material 20 inches long and 6 inches wide by cutting equal squares of length xfrom the corners and folding up the sides.
Write the volume Vof the box as a function of x. Leave it as a product of factors, do not multiply out the factors.
If we write the domain of the box as an open interval in the form (a,b), then what is a =?
and what is b =?
Let P_1 and P_2 be the populations (in hundreds) of Town 1 and Town 2, respectively. The table below shows data for these two populations for five different years.
Find the average rate of change of each population over each of the time intervals below.
(a) From 1980 to 1987, the average rate of change of the population of Town 1 was hundred people per year, and the average rate of change of the population of Town 2 was hundred people per year.
(b) From 1987 to 1999, the average rate of change of the population of Town 1 was hundred people per year, and the average rate of change of the population of Town 2 was hundred people per year.
(c) From 1980 to 1999, the average rate of change of the population of Town 1 was hundred people per year, and the average rate of change of the population of Town 2 was hundred people per year.

static.solution:
(a) From 1980 to 1987, the average rate of change of P_1 is \frac{\Delta P_1}{\Delta t} = \frac{57 - 49}{1987 - 1980} = {\frac{8}{7}}\text{ hundred people per year}. Similarly, from 1980 to 1987, the average rate of change of P_2 is \frac{\Delta P_2}{\Delta t} = \frac{65 - 79}{1987 - 1980} = {-2}\text{ hundred people per year}.
(b) From 1987 to 1999, the average rate of change of P_1 is \frac{\Delta P_1}{\Delta t} = \frac{65 - 57}{1999 - 1987} = \frac{2}{3} \text{ hundred people per year}. Similarly, from 1987 to 1999, the average rate of change of P_2 is \frac{\Delta P_2}{\Delta t} = \frac{51 - 65}{1999 - 1987} = {-\frac{7}{6}}\text{ hundred people per year}.
(c) From 1980 to 1999, the average rate of change of P_1 is \frac{\Delta P_1}{\Delta t} = \frac{65 - 49}{1999 - 1980} = {\frac{16}{19}}\text{ hundred people per year}. Similarly, from 1980 to 1999, the average rate of change of P_2 is \frac{\Delta P_2}{\Delta t} = \frac{51 - 79}{1999 - 1980} = {-\frac{28}{19}} \text{ hundred people per year}.

statement.p: (a) What is the average rate of change of g(x) = -6 - 5 x between the points (-4, 14) and (5,-31)?
answer =

(b) The function g is
?
increasing
decreasing
on the interval -4 \leq x \leq 5.

static.solution:
(a) If y = g(x) then between (-4 , 14) and (5 , -31 ), \hbox{average rate of change of }g =\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \frac{-31 - (14)}{5 -(-4)} = \frac{-31 - 14}{5 + 4}= \frac{-45}{9} = -5.
(b) Since the graph of g is a straight line, the average rate of change of g is constant. By part (a), this constant average rate of change is equal to -5, which is a negative number. Hence g is decreasing on the given interval (and in fact over any interval).

answer =

answer =
(c) Between (x,\ f(x)) and (x+h,\ f(x+h))

In 2005, you have 45 CDs in your collection. In 2008, you have 130 CDs. In 2012, you have 50 CDs. What is the average rate of change in the size of your CD collection between:

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Over the first interval 2005 to 2008, \Delta y = 130 - 45 = 85 and \Delta x = 2008 - 2005 = 3 . Thus the average rate of change during this interval is \frac{ \Delta y }{ \Delta x} = \frac{85}{3}.
(b) Over the interval 2008 to 2012, \Delta y = 50 - 130 = -80 and \Delta x = 2012 - 2008 = 4 . Thus the average rate of change during this interval is \frac{ \Delta y }{ \Delta x} = -20.
(c) Over the interval 2005 to 2012, \Delta y = 50 - 45 = 5 and \Delta x = 2012 - 2005 = 7 . Thus the average rate of change during this interval is \frac{ \Delta y }{ \Delta x} = \frac{5}{7}.

a) What is the average rate of change of f(x) over the interval \ 2.2 \leq x \leq 6.1 \ ?

statement.p: a) For each of the intervals, find the values of \Delta D and \Delta t between the indicated start and end times. Enter your answers in their respective columns in the table below.
b) Based on your results from (a) it follows that the average rate of change of D is constant, it does not depend over which interval of time you choose. What is the constant rate of change of D?

c) Which of the statements below CORRECTLY explains the significance of your answer to part (b)? Select ALL that apply (more than one may apply).
It is the average velocity of the car over the first two hours.
It is the total distance the car travels in five hours.
It is how far the car will travel in a half-hour.
It represents the car's velocity.
It is the acceleration of the car over the five hour time interval.
It is the slope of the line.
None of the above

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) Over the first interval t = 1.5 to t = 4.5, \Delta D = 180 - 60 = 120 and \Delta t = 4.5 - 1.5 = 3 .
Similarly, over the second interval t = 2 to t = 4.5, \Delta D = 180 - 80 = 100 and \Delta t = 4.5 - 2 = 2.5 .
Finally, over the last interval t = 1 to t = 3, \Delta D = 120 - 40 = 80 and \Delta t = 3 - 1 = 2 .
b) Notice that for each of the three intervals in (a) (as well as any other interval), \frac{ \Delta D }{ \Delta t} = 40.
c) There are three correct statements: It represents the car's velocity, It is the average velocity of the car over the first two hours, and It is the slope of the line.

statement.p: The table below gives the average temperature, T, at a depth d, in a borehole in Belleterre, Quebec.
Evaluate \Delta T / \Delta d on the following intervals
a) 125 \leq d \leq 275 \Delta T / \Delta d =
b) 25 \leq d \leq 125 \Delta T / \Delta d =
c) 75 \leq d \leq 200 \Delta T / \Delta d =
d) Which of the statements below correctly explains the significance of your answer to part (c)? Select all that apply (more than one may apply).

li.p: On average, the temperature is changing at a rate of 0.0072 degrees Celsius per minute over the interval 75 \leq d \leq 200 .
0.0072 is the slope of the graph of at d = 75.
The temperature changes by a total of 0.0072 degrees Celsius when moving from a depth 75 meters to 200 meters.
Over the interval from 75 meters to 200 meters, the temperature changes on average at a rate of 0.0072 degrees Celsius per meter.
The temperature is changing at a rate of 0.0072 degrees Celsius per minute when the depth is 75 meters.
None of the above

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) Over the interval d = 125 to d = 275, \Delta T = 6.75 - 5.30 = 1.45 and \Delta d = 275 - 125 = 150 .
Thus \Delta T / \Delta d = 1.45/150 .
b) Over the interval d = 25 to d = 125, \Delta T = 5.30 - 5.50 = -0.2 and \Delta d = 125 - 25 = 100 .
Thus \Delta T / \Delta d = -0.2/100 .
c) Over the interval d = 75 to d = 200, \Delta T = 6.00 - 5.10 = 0.9 and \Delta d = 200 - 75 = 125 .
Thus \Delta T / \Delta d = 0.9/125 .
d) Only the statement Over the interval from 75 meters to 200 meters, the temperature changes on average at a rate of 0.0072 degrees Celsius per meter is correct. All others are incorrect:
The statement, 0.0072 is the slope of the graph of at d = 75, is incorrect since the average rate of change is the slope of the line segment connect the endpoints of the interval.
The statement, The temperature changes by a total of 0.0072 degrees Celsius when moving from a depth 75 meters to 200 meters, is incorrect since the average rate of change is a ratio of the change in temperature divided by the change in depth (not just the total change in temperature.
The statement, On average the temperature is changing at a rate of 0.0072 degrees Celsius per minute over the interval 75 \leq d \leq 200, is incorrect since the units must be degrees Celsius per meter (not minute).
The statement, The temperature is changing at a rate of 0.0072 degrees Celsius per minute when the depth is 75 meters, is incorrect since the average rate of change averages the rates of change at every point in the interval. It is not the rate of the change at just the initial depth.

statement.p: A town has a population of 2000 people at time t=0. In each of the following cases, write a formula for the population P, of the town as a function of year t.
(a) The population increases by 90 people per year.
P= people
(b) The population increases by 1 percent a year.
P= people

static.solution:
(a) The function is linear with initial population of 2000 people and slope of 90, so P=2000 +90 t.
(b) This function is exponential with inital population of 2000 and growth rate of 1 percent, so P=2000 (1.01)^t.

statement.p: Let t be time in seconds and let r(t) be the rate, in gallons per second, that water enters a reservoir: r(t)=600 - 30 t.
(a) Evaluate the expression \ r(5) =

(b) Which one of the statements below best describes the physical meaning of the value of r(5) ?
How many seconds until the water is entering to reservoir at a rate of 5 gallons per second.
The rate at which the rate of the water entering the reservoir is decreasing when 5 gallons remain in the reservoir.
The total amount, in gallons, of water in the reservoir after 5 seconds.
The rate, in gallons per second, at which the water is entering reservoir after 5 seconds.
None of the above
(c) For each of the mathematical expressions below, match one of the statements A - E below which best explains its meaning in practical terms.

li.p: The slope of the graph of r(t).
The vertical intercept of the graph of r(t).
The rate, in gallons per second, at which the water is initially entering the reservoir.
After how many seconds the water stops flowing into the reservoir and starts to drain out.
The average rate, in gallons per second, at which water is flowing out of the reservoir.
The initial amount of water, in gallons, in the reservoir.
The rate at which the rate of water entering the reservoir is decreasing in gallons per second squared.

statement.p: (d) For 0 \leq t \leq 30, when does the reservoir have the most water?
When t = sec.
(e) For 0 \leq t \leq 30, when does the reservoir have the least water?
When t = sec.
(f) If the domain of r(t) is 0 \leq t \leq 30, what is the range of r(t)?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) r(5) = 600 - 30(5)=450.
(b) r(5) = 450 means water is entering the reservoir at 450 gallons per second at time t = 5 seconds.
(c) The vertical intercept first tells us that at time t = 0 seconds, the water is initially flowing in at the rate of 600 gallons per second.
The horizontal intercept tells us that at 600/30 \approx 20 seconds, the flow has stopped.
The slope is -30. This means that the rate at which water enters the reservoir decreases by 30 gallons per second each second. The water is flowing in at a decreasing rate.
(d) The reservoir has more and more water when the rate, r(t), is positive because water is being added. Water is being added until t = 600/30 seconds later when it starts flowing out. This means at t = 600/30, the most water is in the reservoir.
(e) The reservoir has water draining out between t= 600/30 and t= 30, but this amount is not as much as the water that entered between t=0 and t=600/30. Thus, the reservoir had the least amount of water at the beginning when t=0. Remember the function r(t) gives the rate of flow, not the amount of water in the reservoir.
(f) If the domain is specified as 0 \leq t \leq 30 , then the rate varies from 600 gallons per second at t=0 to -300 gallons per second at t=30, so the range is -300 \leq r(t) \leq 600. In interval notation we express the range as \lbrack -300, 600 \rbrack .

statement.p: A report by the US Geological Survey indicates that glaciers in Glacier National Park, Montana, are shrinking. Recent estimates indicate the area covered by glaciers has decreased from over 25.5 \ \mbox{km}^2 in 1850 to about 16.5 \ \mbox{km}^2 in 1995. Let A = f(t) give the area (in square km) t years after 2000, and assume f(t) = 16.2 - 0.062t.

a) Find and explain the meaning of the slope. Which statement best explains its significance?
The area covered by glaciers is decreasing by 62,000 \ \mbox{m}^2 every year.
The total area covered by glaciers decreased by 16.2 \ \mbox{km}^2 from 1850 to 2000.
The area covered by glaciers is decreasing by 62 \ \mbox{m}^2 every year.
The total area covered by glaciers is increasing by 0.062 \ \mbox{km}^2 every year.
The area covered by glaciers is decreasing by 16.2 \ \mbox{km}^2 every year.
None of the above

b) Find and explain the meaning of the A-intercept. Which statement best explains its significance?
The total area covered by glaciers decreased by 16.2 \ \mbox{km}^2 from 1850 to 2000.
The area covered by glaciers in 2000 was 16.2 \ \mbox{km}^2.
The total area covered by glaciers will decrease by 0.062 \ \mbox{km}^2 from 2000 to 2001.
The area covered by glaciers is decreasing by 16.2 \ \mbox{km}^2 every year.
The area covered by glaciers in 2000 was 0.062 \ \mbox{km}^2 .
None of the above

c) For both expressions listed below, enter the letter A-E of the statement which best explains their practical meaning. There are extra, unused statements.
If f(t) = 9, then t is
f( 9 ) is
How much area (in \mbox{km}^2) will be covered by glaciers in 9 years.
The number of years after 2000 that the amount of glacier area that has disappeared is 9 \ \mbox{km}^2.
The amount of glacier area (in \mbox{km}^2) that disappears in 9 years.
The number of years after 2000 that the total area covered by glaciers will be 9 \ \mbox{km}^2.
How much area (in \mbox{km}^2) will be covered by glaciers in 2009.
d) Evaluate f( 9 ) =
e) How much glacier area disappears in 9 years? \mbox{km}^2
f) Solve f(t) = 9 . t = (round your answer to one decimal place)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) The slope is m = 0.062, which tells us that the glacier area in the park goes down by 0.062 \ \mbox{km}^2 per year. Since 1 km = 1,000 m, it follows that 1 \ \mbox{km}^2 = 1,000,000 \ \mbox{m}^2. Equivalently, the slope tells us that the glacier area in the park goes down by 62,000 \ \mbox{m}^2 per year.
b) The A-intercept is b = 16.2, which tells us that in the year 2000, the area was 16.2 \ \mbox{km}^2.
c) f( 9 ) is the amount of area in the park covered by glaciers in 2012 (9 years after 2000). f(t) = 9 signifies how many years after 2000 will the area covered by glaciers be 9 \ \mbox{km}^2.
d) We have f( 9 ) = 16.2 - 0.062( 9) = 15.642
e) m = \frac{ \Delta A }{ \Delta t } = -0.062. Letting \Delta t = 9 we have \frac{ \Delta A }{ 9 } = -0.062 , and therefore \Delta A = - 0.558. So about 0.558 \mbox{km}^2 disappear in 9 years.
f) We have 16.2 - 0.062 t = 9, so that - 0.062 t = -7.2, and finally t \approx 116.1.

statement.p: Find a formula for the linear equation graphed below. You can enlarge the graph by clicking on it.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the function is linear, we can choose any two points (from the graph) to find its formula. We use the form p = b + mh to get the price of an apartment as a function of its height. We use the two points (10, 190000) and (20, 230000). We begin by finding the slope
m = \frac{ \Delta p}{\Delta h} = \frac{230000 - 190000}{20 - 10} = 4000
Next, we substitute a point into our equation using our slope of 4000 dollars per meter of height and solve for b, the p-intercept. We use the point ( 10, 190000): 190000 = b + 4000 \cdot 10 so 150000 = b.
Therefore, p = f(h) = 150000 + 4000 h.

statement.p: Find the equation for the line L (graphed in red) in the figure below. Note the x-coordinate of the point Q is 2, y-coordinate of the point P is 13, and the parabola (graphed in blue) has equation y = x^2 + 2.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Both P and Q lie on y = x^2 +2 , so their coordinates must satisfy that equation. Point Q has x-coordinate 2, so y = 2^2 + 2 = 6. P has y-coordinate 13, so \begin{aligned} 13 \amp = x^2 + 2, \\ x^2 \amp = 11, \quad\mbox{so} \\ x \amp = \pm \sqrt{11}. \end{aligned} Thus x = - \sqrt{11} because we know from the graph that x \lt 0. Using coordinates of P and Q, we know that
m = \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \frac{13-6}{- \sqrt{11} - 2} = \frac{7}{- \sqrt{11} - 2}.
Since y = 6 when x = 2, we have y = \left( \frac{7}{- \sqrt{11} - 2} \right) (x-2) + 6.

Find the zeros, if any, of the function y = 4\!\left(x+8\right)^{2}-8.
Enter your answer as a comma separated list. If no zeros exist, enter NONE.
The zeros are x =

solution.p: We can solve the equation 4\!\left(x+8\right)^{2}-8 = 0 algebraically. \begin{array}{rcl} 4\!\left(x+8\right)^{2}-8 \amp = \amp 0 \\ 4(x+8)^2 \amp = \amp + 8 \\ (x+8)^2 \amp = \amp + 2 \\ x+8 \amp = \amp \pm \sqrt{ + 2} \\ x \amp = \amp -8 \pm \sqrt{ + 2}. \end{array}

statement.p: Find the zero(s) (if any) of the function y = x^2 - 15 x + 50
Enter your answer as a comma separated list. If no real zeros exist, enter NONE .
The zero(s) is/are x =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
To find the zeros, we solve the equation 0 = x^2 - 15 x + 50 . We see that this is factorable, as y = (x - 10)(x - 5). Therefore, the zeros occur where x= 10 and x= 5.

statement.p: If a ball is thrown straight up into the air with an initial velocity of 100 ft/s, its height in feet after t second is given by y = {100}t - 16t^2. Find the average velocity (include units, ) for the time period begining when t = 2 seconds and lasting
(i) 0.5 seconds
Average velocity:
(ii) 0.1 seconds
Average velocity:
(iii) 0.01 seconds
Average velocity:

statement.p: The formula for the volume of a cube with side length s is V = s^3. The formula for the surface area of a cube is A = 6s^2.
(a) Find the formula for the function s = f(A).

Which of the statements best explains the meaning of s = f(A)?
The side length for a cube of surface area A
The side length for a cube of volume V
The volume of a cube of side length s
The surface area of a cube of side length s
(b) If V = g(s), find a formula for g(f(A)).

Which of the statements best explains the meaning of g(f(A))?
The volume for a cube of side length s
The surface area for a cube of side length s
The volume for a cube with surface area A
The surface area for a cube of volume V

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) To write s as a function of A, we solve A=6s^2 for s s^2=\frac{A}{6}\qquad\hbox{ so} \qquad s=f(A)=+\sqrt{\frac{A}{6}} Because the length of a side of a cube is positive.
The function f gives the side of a cube in terms of its area A.
(b) Substituting s=f(A)=\sqrt{A/6} in the formula V=g(s)=s^3 gives the volume, V, as a function of surface area, A, V=g(f(A))=s^3=\left(\sqrt{\frac{A}{6}}\right)^3.

statement.p: The cost (in dollars) of producing x air conditioners is C = g(x) = 560 + 40 x. Find a formula for the inverse function g^{-1}(C).

static.solution:
SOLUTION
We solve the equation C=g(x)= for x. Subtract 560 from both sides and divide both sides by 40 to get x=\frac{1}{40}(C-560). So g^{-1}(C)=\frac{1}{40}(C-560).

statement.p: (a) Find a formula for the perimeter of a square of side length s.

Which of the statements best explains the meaning of f(4)?
The side length of a square of perimeter P
The area of a square of side length 4
The side length of a square of area 4
The perimeter of a square of side length 4

Which of the statements best explains the meaning of f^{-1}(32)?
The side length of a square of perimeter 32
The area of a square of side length 32
The side length of a square of area 32
The perimeter of a square of side length 32
(d) Find a formula for the inverse function.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The perimeter of a square of side length s is P = f(s) = 4s.
(b) Thus, f(4) = 16, which is the perimeter of a square of side length 4.
(c) The inverse function s = f^{-1}(P) = P/4, so f^{-1}(32) = 8, which is the side length of a square of perimeter 32.
(d) The inverse function is obtained by solving P = f(s) = 4s for s = f^{-1}(P) = P/4.

The inverse function, f^{-1}(V), gives the time, in seconds after leaving, at which the speed is V \ \mbox{km/hr}.

SOLUTION
G(11) is the output corresponding to the input of t=11. So G(11) represents the GDP for the year 2001 (11 years after 1990).
The input to the G^{-1} function is billions of dollars, so its output is a time in years after 1990. Thus, G^{-1}(9873) represents the number of years after 1990 at which the GDP is 9873 billion dollars.

(b) The graph of f(x) - 5 must contain the point
(c) The graph of f(x + 2 ) + 7 must contain the point

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The translation f(x-6) moves the graph to the right 6 units. The y-coordinate is not changed, but the x-coordinate is 9 + 6 = 15, and the new point is therefore (15, 4).
(b) The translation f(x)-5 moves the graph down 5 units. The x-coordinate is not changed, but the y-coordinate is 4 - 5 = -1, and the new point is therefore (9, -1).
(c) The translation f(x+2) + 7 moves the graph both to the left 2 units and up 7 units. Both coordinates will therefore change. The x-coordinate is 9 - 2 = 7, the y-coordinate is 4 + 7 = 11, and the new point is therefore (7, 11).

statement.p: Let y = f(x) be a periodic function whose values are given below. Find the period, amplitude, and midline.
(a) The period of the graph is
(b) The midline of the graph is
(c) The amplitude of the graph is

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The graph appears to have a period of 60. Every change in the x value of 60 brings us back to the same y value.
(b) The midline of the graph is 7 since \mbox{midline} = \frac{ y_{max} + y_{min} }{2} = \frac{ 17 - 3 }{2} = 7.
(c) The amplitude is how much the maximum or minimum y value differs from the average (midline). Since the maximum y value is 17 and the midline is 7, the amplitude is 17 - 7 = 10.

statement.p: A ferris wheel is 140 meters in diameter and boarded at its lowest point (6 O'Clock) from a platform which is 8 meters above ground. The wheel makes one full rotation every 14 minutes, and at time t = 0 you are at the loading platform (6 O'Clock). Let h = f(t) denote your height above ground in meters after t minutes.
(a) What is the period of the function h = f(t)?
period = Include units in your answer.
(b) What is the midline of the function h = f(t)?
h = Include units in your answer.
(c) What is the amplitude of the function h = f(t)?
amplitude = Include units in your answer.

Which (if any) of the graphs A-F represents two full revolutions of the ferris wheel described above?
Select
A
B
C
D
E
F
None of the graphs above

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Since the ferris wheel makes one full rotation every 14 minutes, the period is 14 minutes.
(b) The midline is the height when you are halfway up the ferris wheel. If the ferris wheel has a diameter of 140 meters and the loading platform is 8 meters above the ground, the height midway up the ferris wheel is \frac{140}{2} + 8 = 78. So the midline is h = 78 meters.
(c) The amplitude is the difference of your height on top of the ferris wheel and your height at the midline (or halfway up the ferris wheel). When you are highest on the ferris wheel, your height is 140 + 8 = 148. Therefore the amplitude is 148 - 78 = 70 meters.
(d) Based on the answers above, the correct answer is graph B.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) The weight's initial distance from the ceiling is at its smallest value 3 cm. Thus the weight starts at its closest position from the ceiling. It then begins to head down away from the ceiling towards the floor.
(b) The period of the graph is 0.5, therefore it takes the weight 0.5 seconds to go through one full oscillation and return to its starting position.
(c) The weight gets as close as 3 cm to the ceiling.
(d) The weight falls as far as 19 cm from the ceiling.
(e) The amplitude of the graph is the distance of the maximum (or minimum) y value from the midline. In this case the midline is d=11 and the maximum value is d=19, so the amplitude is 8.

statement.p: Find t for the following terminal points:
What is the exact radian angle measure for 45^{\circ} as a fraction of \pi? radians
What is a decimal approximation for the radian angle measure for 45^{\circ} accurate to three decimal places? radians

static.solution:
SOLUTION
To convert 45^{\circ} to radians, multiply by \pi/180^{\circ}:
\displaystyle 45^{\circ} \cdot \left( \frac{\pi}{180^{\circ}} \right) = \frac{45 \pi}{180}
Thus we say that the radian measure of a 45^{\circ} angle is \frac{45 \pi}{180} which is approximately 0.785398 radians.

Thus we say that the radian measure of a 22^{\circ} angle is \frac{22 \pi}{180} which is approximately 0.383972 radians.

statement.p: Question 30:
a) Write an expression (involving the variable a and h ) for the slope of the line segment joining S and T in the figure above.
Slope = (an expression involving the variables a and h)
b) Evaluate your expression for a = 1.6 and h = 0.01. Round your answer to two decimal places.
Slope = (a value rounded to two decimal places)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) The coordinate of the point S are (x_0,y_0) = ( a, \sin{(a)} ) while the coordinates of the point T are (x_1,y_1) = ( a+h, \sin{(a+h)} ). Thus the slope between these two points can be expressed as
\displaystyle \mbox{slope} = \frac{ y_1 - y_0 }{x_1-x_0} = \frac{ \sin{(a+h)} - \sin{(a)} }{ (a+h) - a} = \frac{ \sin{(a+h)} - \sin{(a)} }{h}
b) Plugging in the values a = 1.6 and h = 0.01 into the expression above you find \mbox{slope} \approx -0.03.

statement.p: Find period, amplitude, and midline of the following function: y = -6 \cos{(7 \pi x + 2)} - 9
(a) The period of the graph is
(b) The midline of the graph is y =
(c) The amplitude of the graph is

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the maximum value of the cosine function is 1 and the minimum is -1, the expression -6 \cos{(7 \pi x + 2 )} varies between - 6 and 6 in value. The subtraction of 9 means that y = -6 \cos{(7 \pi x + 2)} - 9 varies between -15 and -3. The expression 7 \pi x + 2 inside the cosine function is a horizontal compression which affects the period and a phase shift left 2 units. The phase shift left 2 units does not change the period, amplitude or the midline.
(a) The period is equal to \frac{ 2 \pi}{7 \pi} = \frac{2}{7}.
(b) The midline is the average value, \mbox{midline} = \frac{ -3 - 15}{2} = -9 which can be determined by glancing at the coefficient added (subtracted) to the end of expression -6 \cos{(7 \pi x + 2 )}.
(c) The amplitude is the variation from the midline to the maximum or minimum. In this example \mbox{amplitude} = -3 - (-9) = 6. This can quickly be determined by taking the absolute value of the coefficient -6 in front of the cosine in the function y = -6 \cos{(7 \pi x + 2)} - 9.

statement.p: Find a possible formula for the trigonometric function graphed below. Use x as the independent variable in your formula.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
This function resembles a cosine curve in that it attains its maximum when x = 0. We know that the smallest value it attains is 0 and that its maximum value is 8. Therefore its midline is y = \frac{ 8 + 0}{2} = 4, and its amplitude is 8 - 4 = 4. Thus in the equation f(x) = A \cos{(Bx)} + k we know that A = 4 and k = 4. Since the graph has a period of 8, the value for B = \frac{2 \pi}{\mbox{period}} = \frac{2 \pi}{8} = \frac{\pi}{4}. Finally we have a formula: f(x) = 4+4 \cos{ \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \ x \right)}.

statement.p: Find a formula for the trigonometric function graphed below. Use x as the independent variable in your formula.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
This function resembles a cosine curve in that it attains its minimum (not midline) when x = 0. Since the value is at its minimum (not maximum) at x = 0, we need to use the formula f(x) = - \cos{(x)}. We know that the smallest value it attains is 0, that its midline is y = 14, so its amplitude is 14 as well. Thus in the equation f(x) = -A \cos{(Bx)} + k we know that A = 14 and k = 14. Since the graph has a period of 10, the value for B = \frac{2 \pi}{\mbox{period}} = \frac{2 \pi}{10} = \frac{\pi}{5}. Finally we have a formula: f(x) = 14-14 \cos{ \left( \frac{\pi}{5} x \right) }.

statement.p: A ferris wheel is 40 meters in diameter and boarded at ground level. The wheel makes one full rotation every 8 minutes, and at time t = 0 you are at the 9 o'clock position and descending. Let f(t) denote your height (in meters) above ground at t minutes. Find a formula for f(t).

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the diameter is 40 meters, your height would be 20 meters when you are halfway up the ferris wheel, so the midline is y = k = 20. Your maximum height is 40 meters, so the amplitude is A = 20. The period is 8 minutes, so the constant B = \frac{ 2 \pi}{8}. At t = 0, the 9 o'clock position would be halfway up the ferris wheel. We want the graph to be at its midline when t = 0, so we want to use the sine function. We also want the graph to begin decreasing at a first since the ferris wheel is descending, so we need to use a function of the form f(t) = -A \sin{(Bt)} + k: f(t) = -20 \sin{\left( \frac{2 \pi}{8} \ t \right)}+20.

statement.p: Suppose Q = 30.8(0.751)^t. Give the starting value a, the growth factor b, and the growth rate r if Q = a \cdot b^t = a(1+r)^t.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The starting value is a=2090. The growth rate is r=-3.7%= -0.037, so b=1+r=0.963. We have P = 2090\cdot 0.963^{t}.

statement.p: (a) The annual inflation rate is 3.8% per year. If a movie ticket costs $9.00 today, find a formula for p, the price of a movie ticket t years from today, assuming that movie tickets keep up with inflation.
(b) According to your formula, how much will a movie ticket cost in 30 years?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) We assume that the price of a movie ticket increases at the rate of 3.8% per year. This means that the price is rising exponentially, so a formula for p is of the form p=ab^t. We have a=9.00 and b=1+r=1.038. Thus, a formula for p is p = 9.00(1.038)^t.
(b) In 30 years t=30 we have p = 9.00(1.038)^{30} \approx 27.55.

statement.p: In the year 2003, a total of 7.2 million passengers took a cruise vacation. The global cruise industry has been growing at 9% per year for the last decade. Assume that this growth rate continues.

The populations, P, of six towns with time t in years are given by

Answer the following questions regarding the populations of the six towns above. Whenever you need to enter several towns in one answer, enter your answer as a comma separated list of numbers. For example if town 1, town 2, town 3, and town 4, are all growing you could enter 1, 2, 3, 4 ; or 2, 4, 1, 3 ; or any other order of these four numerals separated by commas.

(b) Which of the towns are shrinking?

(d) Which town is shrinking the fastest?
What is the annual percentage decay RATE of that town? %

(f) Which town has the smallest initial population?

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The formula f(t) = ab^t represents exponential growth if the base b > 1 and exponential decay if 0 \lt b \lt 1. Towns 2, 5, 4 are growing and towns 6, 1, 3 are shrinking.
Town 4 is growing the fastest since its growth factor of 1.187 is the largest. Since 1.187 - 1 = 0.187, it is growing at a rate of 18.7%. Town 1 is shrinking the fastest since its decay factor of 0.78 is the smallest. Since 1 - 0.78 = 0.22, it is shrinking at a rate of 22%.
In the exponential function f(t) = ab^t, the parameter a gives the value of the function when t = 0. We see that town 6 has the largest initial population (2800) and town 5 has the smallest initial population (500).

statement.p: (a) Determine whether function whose values are given in the table below could be linear or exponential.

li.p: linear
exponential

statement.p: Find a possible formula for this function.
(b) Determine whether function whose values are given in the table below could be linear or exponential.

li.p: linear
exponential

statement.p: Find a possible formula for this function.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) If a function is linear, then the differences in successive function values will be constant. If a function is exponential, the ratios of successive function values will remain constant. Now h(1) - h(0) = 8 - 14 = -6, and h(2) - h(1) = 2 - 8 = -6 (and similarly for the remaining intervals). Thus, h(x) is linear.
We know that h(x) is linear, so h(x) = m\,x + b for some constants m and b. We know that h(0) = 14, so 14 = m\cdot 0 + b = b, and b = 14. Then h(1) = 8, so 8 = m\cdot 1 + 14, so m = 8 - 14 = -6, and we have h(x) = -6\,x + 14.
(b) As before, if a function is linear, then the differences in successive function values will be constant. If a function is exponential, the ratios of successive function values will remain constant. Now i(1) - i(0) = 12.6 - 14 = -1.4, and i(2) - i(1) = 11.34 - 12.6 = -1.26 (and similarly for the remaining intervals). Thus, i(x) is not linear.
On the other hand, \begin{aligned} \frac{i(1)}{i(0)} \amp = 0.9\\ \frac{i(2)}{i(1)} \amp = 0.9 \end{aligned} (and similarly for the remaining intervals). Thus i(x) is exponential.
We know that i(x) is linear, so i(x) = a\,b^x for some constants a and b. We know that i(0)=14, so \begin{aligned} 14 \amp = i(0)\\ 14 \amp = ab^0\\ 14 \amp = a(1). \end{aligned} Thus, a=14. Also \begin{aligned} 12.6 \amp = i(1)\\ 12.6 \amp = 14\,b. \end{aligned} Thus b = 0.9, and we have i(x) = 14\cdot 0.9^x.

statement.p: A population has size 8000 at time t = 0, with t in years.
(a) If the population decreases by 125 people per year, find a formula for the population, P, at time t.
(b) If the population decreases by 6% per year, find a formula for the population, P, at time t.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) The population is decreasing linearly, with a slope of -125 people/year, so P(t) = 8000 - 125 t.
b) The population is decreasing exponentially with decay factor 1 - 0.06 = 0.94, so P(t) = 8000 (1- 0.06)^t=8000(0.94)^t

Newton's law of cooling states that the temperature of an object changes at a rate proportional to the difference between its temperature and that of its surroundings. Suppose that the temperature of a cup of coffee obeys Newton's law of cooling. If the coffee has a temperature of 210 degrees Fahrenheit when freshly poured, and 1.5 minutes later has cooled to 195 degrees in a room at 78 degrees, determine when the coffee reaches a temperature of 155 degrees.
The coffee will reach a temperature of 155 degrees in minutes.

The total number of people infected with a virus often grows like a logistic curve. Suppose that 25 people originally have the virus, and that in the early stages of the virus (with time, t, measured in weeks), the number of people infected is increasing exponentially with k=1.8. It is estimated that, in the long run, approximately 7250 people become infected.
(a) Use this information to find a logistic function to model this situation.

(b) Sketch a graph of your answer to part (a). Use your graph to estimate the length of time until the rate at which people are becoming infected starts to decrease. What is the vertical coordinate at this point?
vertical coordinate =

static.solution:
(a) We know that a logistic curve can be modeled by the function P=\frac{L}{1+Ce^{-kt}} where C=(L-P_0)/P_0 and P is the number of people infected by the virus at a particular time t. We know that L is the limiting value, or the maximal number of people infected with the virus, so in our case L=7250. We are also told that initially there are only 25 people infected with the virus so that we get P_0=25. Thus we have C = \frac{L-P_0}{P_0} = \frac{7250-25}{25} = 289. We are also told that in the early stages of the virus, infection grows exponentially with k=1.8. Thus we get that the logistic function for people infected is P=\frac{7250}{1+289 e^{-1.8 t}}.
(b) Graphing this solution, we see
Looking at the graph we see that the the point at which the rate changes from increasing to decreasing, the inflection point, occurs at roughly t=3.25 giving a value of P=3750. Thus after roughly 3750 people have been infected, the rate of infection starts dropping.

If \cos(\phi) = 0.8347 and 3 \pi /2 \leq \phi \leq 2 \pi, approximate the following to four decimal places.
(a) \sin( \phi ) = (Round to four decimal places.)
(b) \tan( \phi ) = (Round to four decimal places.)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) We begin by using the Pythagorean Identity to find \sin{ ( \phi ) }. Since \sin^2{ ( \phi )} + \cos^2{ ( \phi ) } =1, we have
\sin^2{ ( \phi ) } + \left( 0.8347 \right)^2 = 1
\sin^2{ ( \phi ) } = 1 - \left( 0.8347 \right)^2
\sin{ ( \phi ) } = \pm \sqrt{0.3033} \approx \pm 0.5507 .
Since 3 \pi /2 \leq \phi \leq 2 \pi, \sin{ ( \phi ) } is negative, so \sin{ ( \phi ) } \approx - 0.5507.
b) \tan{ ( \phi ) }= \frac{ \sin{ ( \phi )}}{\cos{ ( \phi )}} = \frac{- 0.5507}{0.8347} \approx -0.6598

By sketching a graph, we see that there are four solutions:

Suppose the angle \theta is in the first quadrant, 0 \leq \theta \leq \pi /2, and \displaystyle \cos(\theta) = \frac{1}{8}. Find exact values (as fractions, not decimal approximations) for the following.
(a) \csc(\theta) =
(b) \cot(\theta) =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) Since \csc{ ( \theta ) } = \frac{1}{\sin{ ( \theta )}}, we begin by using the Pythagorean Identity to find \sin{ ( \theta ) }. Since \cos^2{ ( \theta )} + \sin^2{ ( \theta ) }=1, we have
\begin{array}{rcl} \left( \frac{1}{8} \right)^2 + \sin^2{ ( \theta ) } \amp = \amp 1 \\[1ex] \sin^2{ ( \theta )} \amp = \amp 1 - \frac{1}{64} \\[1ex] \sin{ ( \theta ) } \amp = \amp \pm \sqrt{ \frac{63}{64} }. \end{array}
Since 0 \le \theta \le \frac{\pi}{2}, \sin{ ( \theta ) } \ge 0, so \sin{ ( \theta ) } = \sqrt{ \frac{63}{64}}. Thus, \csc{ ( \theta )} = \sqrt{ \frac{64}{63}}.
(b) Since \cot{ ( \theta ) }= \frac{ \cos{ ( \theta ) }}{\sin{ ( \theta ) }}, we have \cot{ ( \theta ) } = \frac{1/8}{\sqrt{63/64}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{63}}.

statement.p: You wish to pack a cardboard box inside a wooden crate. In order to have room for the packing materials, you need to leave a 0.5 \ \mbox{ft} space around the front, back, and sides of the box, and a 1 \ \mbox{ft} space around the top and bottom of the box.
If the cardboard box is x feet long, (x+2) feet wide, and (x-1) feet deep, find a formula in terms of x for the amount of packing material, M, needed.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Let M be the amount of packing material you will need, then
M = \left( \mbox{Volume of crate} \right) -\left( \hbox{ Volume of box} \right) = V_c-V_b where V_c and V_b are the volumes of the crate and box, respectively. We have for the box's volume, V_b = x(x+ 2)(x-1).
The wooden crate must be 1 ft longer than the cardboard box, so its length is (x + 1). This gives the required 0.5 ft clearance between the crate and the front and back of the box. Similarly, the crate's width must be 1 ft greater than the box's width of (x + 2), and its depth must be 2 ft greater than the box's depth of (x-1).
We have for the crate's volume V_c = (x+1)(x+2+1)(x-1+2) = (x+1)(x+3)(x+1). Thus, the total amount of packing material will be M = V_c - V_b = (x+1)(x+3)(x+1)-x(x+2)(x-1).
The formula for M is a difference of two third-degree polynomials. The format is not terribly convenient, so we simplify the formula by multiplying the factors for V_b and V_c and gathering like terms. Then for M we have \begin{aligned} M \amp = (x+1)(x+3)(x+1)-x(x+2)(x-1) \\ \amp = ( x^3 + 5 x^2 + 7 x + 3 )-( x^3 + 1 x^2 - 2 x) \\ \amp = 4 x^2 + 9 x + 3. \end{aligned}

statement.p: An open-top box is to be constructed from a 6 \ \mbox{in} by 14 \ \mbox{in} rectangular sheet of tin by cutting out squares of equal size at each corner, then folding up the resulting flaps. Let x denote the length of the side of each cut-out square. Assume negligible thickness.
(a) Find a formula for the volume, V, of the box as a function of x. \ \ V(x) =
(b) For what values of x does the formula from part (a) make sense in the context of the problem?
(c) On a separate piece of paper, sketch a graph of the volume function.
(d) What, approximately, is the maximum volume of the box?
(include units: )

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) V(x) = x(6-2x)(14-2x)
(b) Values of x for which V(x) makes sense are 0\lt x\lt 3, since if x\lt 0 or x> 3 the volume is negative. If x > 7, then you would need to cut out a corner which is larger then the length of each side of the paper.
(c)
(d) Using a graphing calculator, we find the peak between x=0 and x= 3 to occur at x \approx 1.306. The maximum volume is V \approx 50.39 \ \mbox{in}^3.

statement.p: Find the horizontal asymptote, if it exists, of the rational function below. If the function does not have a horizontal asymptote, enter NONE.
The horizontal asymptote has equation

static.solution:
SOLUTION
g(x) = \frac{(-1 - x)(-7 - 2 x)}{2 x^2 + 1} = -\frac{-2 x^2}{2 x^2} = -\frac{-2}{2} \quad\mbox{as}\quad x \to \pm \infty. Therefore g(x) has a horizontal asymptote at y = -\frac{-2}{2}.

statement.p: Compare and discuss the long-run behaviors of the functions below. In each blank, enter either the constant or the polynomial that the rational function behaves like as x \to \pm \infty:
\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^3 + 3}{x^3 - 8} , \displaystyle g(x) = \frac{x^2 + 3}{x^3 - 8} , and \displaystyle h(x) = \frac{x^4 + 3}{x^3 - 8}
f(x) will behave like the function y = as x \to \pm \infty.
g(x) will behave like the function y = as x \to \pm \infty.
h(x) will behave like the function y = as x \to \pm \infty.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
For the function f(x), f(x) \to 1 as x \rightarrow \pm \infty since for large values of x, f(x) \approx \frac{x^3}{x^3}=1.
The function g(x) will behave like y= \frac{x^2}{x^3}= 0 for large values of x. Thus, g \rightarrow 0 as x \rightarrow \pm \infty.
The function h(x) \approx \frac{x^4}{x^3} = x for large values of x. Thus, as x \rightarrow \pm \infty, h(x) approaches the line y=x.

statement.p: Let \displaystyle r(x) = \frac{p(x)}{q(x)}, where p and q are polynomials of degrees m and n respectively.
(a) If r(x) \to 0 as x \to \infty, then

li.p: None of the above

statement.p:
(b) If r(x) \to k as x \to \infty, with k \not= 0, then
m \lt n
m > n
m = n
None of the above

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) If \lim_{x\to\infty}r(x)=0, then the degree of the denominator is greater than the degree of the numerator, so n>m.
(b) If \lim_{x\to\infty} r(x)=k, with k\ne0, the degree of the numerator and denominator must be equal, so n=m.

statement.p: Find all zeros and vertical asymptotes of the rational function
\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^2 - 16}{-x^3-16 x^2}.
If there is more than one answer, enter your answers as a comma separated list. If there is no solution, enter NONE. Do not leave a blank empty.
(a) The function has x-intercept(s) at x =
(b) The function has y-intercept(s) at y =
(c) The function has vertical asymptote(s) when x =
(d) The function has horizontal asymptote(s) when y =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Note that \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x^2-16}{-x^3 - 16 x^2} = \frac{(x-4)(x+4)}{-x^2(x+16)}. The x-intercepts occur when y = 0. This will be when x = \pm 4. The y-intercepts are when x = 0, but this makes the function undefined, so there are no y intercepts. Then, vertical asymptotes occur when the denominator goes to zero. This occurs when x = 0 or x = -4. Finally, a horizontal asymptote is seen as x\to\pm\infty if f(x) has a limiting value there. In this case, as x\to\pm\infty, we see that the denominator grows as x^3 while the numerator grows as x^2. Thus f(x)\to 0, and this is the horizontal asymptote.

There is a vertical asymptote at x = 1 such that \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = \infty and \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = \infty.

statement.p: Find a possible formula for the function graphed below. The x-intercept is marked with a point located at (1, 0), and the y-intercept is marked with a point located at (0, -0.25). The asymptotes are y = -1 and x = 4. Give your formula as a reduced rational function.
(Click on graph to enlarge)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the graph has an asymptote at x=4, let the denominator be (x-4).
Since the graph has a zero at x= 1, let the numerator be (x-1).
Since the long-run behavior tends toward y = -1 as x \to \pm \infty, the ratio of the leading terms should be -1.
So a possible formula is \displaystyle y = f(x) = - \frac{x-1}{x-4}. You can check that the y-intercept is y = -0.25, as it should be.

statement.p: Find a possible formula for the function graphed below. The x-intercepts are marked with points located at (5, 0) and (-4, 0), while the y-intercept is marked with a point located at \left( 0, -\frac{5}{3} \right). The asymptotes are y = -1, x = -3, and x = 4. Give your formula as a reduced rational function.
(Click on graph to enlarge)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the graph has a vertical asymptotes at x=4 and x = -3, let the denominator be (x-4)(x + 3).
Since the graph has zeros at x= 5 and x = -4 let the numerator be (x-5)(x + 4).
Since the long-run behavior tends toward y = -1 as x \to \pm \infty, the ratio of the leading terms should be -1.
So a possible formula is \displaystyle y = f(x) = -\frac{(x-5)(x + 4)}{(x-4)(x + 3)}. You can check that the y-intercept is y = -\frac{5}{3}, as it should be.

statement.p: Let f(x) = \frac{ 6 x - 6}{7 x + 4}. Find and simplify f^{-1}(x) =

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Start with our property of inverse functions f \left( f^{-1}(x) \right) = x, and substitute y for f^{-1}(x) to get f(y)=x. Now, using the formula for f we get \displaystyle f(y) = \frac{6 y - 6}{7 y + 4} =x and solving for y yields \begin{aligned} \frac{6 y - 6}{7 y + 4} \amp =x \\ 6 y -6 \amp = x(7 y+4) \\ 6 y -6 \amp = 7 xy + 4 x \\ 6 y- 7 yx \amp = 4 x +6 \\ y(6- 7 x) \amp = 4 x +6 \\ y \amp = \frac{4 x + 6}{6 - 7 x}. \end{aligned} Now replacing y by f^{-1}(x), we have our formula, f^{-1}(x) = \frac{4 x + 6}{6 - 7 x}.

statement.p: Let t be the time in weeks. At time t=0, organic waste is dumped into a pond. The oxygen level in the pond at time t is given by
\displaystyle f(t) = \frac{t^{2}-t+1}{t^{2}+1}.
Assume f(0)=1 is the normal level of oxygen.
(a) On a separate piece of paper, graph this function.
(b) What will happen to the oxygen level in the lake as time goes on?

li.p: Choose One
The oxygen level will continue to decrease in the long-run.
The oxygen level will continue to increase in the long-run.
The oxygen level will eventually return to its normal level in the long-run.
It cannot determine based on the given information.

statement.p: (c) Approximately how many weeks must pass before the oxygen level returns to 80% of its normal level?
weeks (Round to at least two decimal places.)

p.m: \text{The oxygen level will eventually return to its normal level in the long-run.}

static.solution:
SOLUTION
(a) A graph of f for 0 \leq t \leq 20 and 0 \leq y \leq 1.1 is shown in the figure below:
At t=0 the oxygen is at its normal level in the pond. The level decreases sharply for the first week after the waste is dumped into the pond. The oxygen level reaches its minimum of approximately one half the normal level by the end of the first week. Then the level begins to increase.
(b) Eventually, the oxygen level in the pond will once again approach the normal level of one. This is visualized by the gray horizontal asymptote y = 1 in the graph above.
(c) The line y= 0.8 is shown in figure above. After the level has reached its minimum, we can approximate the intersection of f and y= 0.8 at t \approx 4.791. Thus, it takes about 4.791 weeks for the level to return to 80% normal.
